title: Finding the Popular Manga
text:
Manga and manhwa have exploded in global popularity over the past decade, reaching audiences far beyond Japan and Korea. Platforms like MangaDex, Webtoon, and MyAnimeList host thousands of series across every imaginable genre, from fantasy epics to slice-of-life romances. As a fan myself, I’ve often wondered why certain series become massively popular while others—sometimes with similar art or storytelling—barely get noticed.
This project explores the data behind that question. By gathering information on ratings, number of followers, genres, and other characteristics of manga and manhwa series, I aim to better understand what factors might be associated with a series’ popularity or critical reception.
This topic is both interesting and data-rich—it allows for real-world data collection through APIs and encourages questions that connect art, culture, and statistics.

title: Finding the Popular Manga
text:
Manga and manhwa have exploded in global popularity over the past decade, reaching audiences far beyond Japan and Korea. Platforms like MangaDex, Webtoon, and MyAnimeList host thousands of series across every imaginable genre, from fantasy epics to slice-of-life romances. As a fan myself, I’ve often wondered why certain series become massively popular while others—sometimes with similar art or storytelling—barely get noticed.
This project explores the data behind that question. By gathering information on ratings, number of followers, genres, and other characteristics of manga and manhwa series, I aim to better understand what factors might be associated with a series’ popularity or critical reception.
This topic is both interesting and data-rich—it allows for real-world data collection through APIs and encourages questions that connect art, culture, and statistics.

title: Finding the Popular Manga
text:
Motivating Question
What features of a manga or manhwa are most strongly associated with its popularity and rating?
Specifically, I hope to explore whether characteristics such as the number of chapters, publication status (ongoing or completed), or genre variety play a role in how well a series is received by readers.
This question connects nicely to statistical analysis techniques—correlation, regression, and visualization—and allows for a creative but data-driven approach to understanding fan behavior and storytelling trends.

title: Finding the Popular Manga
section: Ethical Considerations and Good Scraping Practice
text:
Ethical Considerations and Good Scraping Practice
Before gathering any data, I reviewed the MangaDex API documentation and confirmed that the site explicitly provides public access for metadata queries under a permissive license. The API is designed for developers and researchers to retrieve information about manga titles, tags, authors, and ratings, so no scraping of copyrighted text or images was necessary.
I also followed general ethical web-scraping practices, including:
Respecting rate limits and adding time delays between requests.
Using a descriptive user-agent header to identify my script.
Collecting only publicly available metadata (no private or user-specific data).
Avoiding excessive or repeated requests that could burden the site’s servers.
Because the API data is public and intended for third-party use, this project complies with ethical data-collection standards.

title: Finding the Popular Manga
text:
Summary of Data Collection Process
To collect my data, I used the MangaDex REST API, which returns JSON-formatted data for manga series. Getting started required just a few lines of Python using the requests library. The overall process can be summarized in four main steps:
Identify an API endpoint. MangaDex provides endpoints like /manga to retrieve metadata for many titles at once. The official documentation lists query parameters (such as genre, publication status, and rating order) that make it easy to pull a wide variety of series.
Make API calls with requests. In Python, I used:
import requests

response = requests.get("https://api.mangadex.org/manga", params={"limit": 100})
data = response.json()
This returns a structured dictionary containing details for each series, including title, description, tags, publication status, and relationships (e.g., authors).
Extract and clean relevant fields. Each manga entry contains nested attributes, so I parsed out features such as:
Title
Average rating
Number of followers
Status (ongoing/completed)
Genres/tags
Year started These variables form the backbone of my dataset.
Store and combine results. I looped through multiple API pages until I had well over 200 unique manga and manhwa entries. The cleaned data was then stored in a CSV file for later analysis using pandas.
For anyone wanting to try something similar, the MangaDex API is an excellent place to start. It’s free, openly documented, and returns rich metadata with minimal setup.

title: Matplotlib vs. Seaborn: Same Plot, Different Styles
text: The goal is to demonstrate the strengths that both the matplotlib and seaborn libraries have when plotting graphs. Only basic data will be plotted to illustrate the basic functions each library has and the special features for plotting each library has. I will be plotting the same graphs (with some minor differences) using both libraries. When working on a project you may just want a “quick and dirty” graph that just shows you the data. Othertimes, you may want to make a nice plot to present to others. We will inspect both of the libraries so you can learn the advantages of both and see which one is more time efficient and better for you and your situation. Since the main purpose is to compare these libraries, I will not go into major detail the syntax and every capability of each library. For more information on how to use the seaborn library, visit Seaborn Tutorial. For more information on how to use the matplot library, visit Matplotlib Tutorial.

title: Matplotlib vs. Seaborn: Same Plot, Different Styles
text: The goal is to demonstrate the strengths that both the matplotlib and seaborn libraries have when plotting graphs. Only basic data will be plotted to illustrate the basic functions each library has and the special features for plotting each library has. I will be plotting the same graphs (with some minor differences) using both libraries. When working on a project you may just want a “quick and dirty” graph that just shows you the data. Othertimes, you may want to make a nice plot to present to others. We will inspect both of the libraries so you can learn the advantages of both and see which one is more time efficient and better for you and your situation. Since the main purpose is to compare these libraries, I will not go into major detail the syntax and every capability of each library. For more information on how to use the seaborn library, visit Seaborn Tutorial. For more information on how to use the matplot library, visit Matplotlib Tutorial.

title: Matplotlib vs. Seaborn: Same Plot, Different Styles
text:
Characteristics

Matplotlib

Foundational library

Other graphing libraries are based off the matplotlib library. Even using other graphing libraries such as seaborn, you still need to import matplotlib and use some of its functions.

Flexible but verbose

Its flexible in the many different features availbale, but it requires you to type a lot of code just to even label the graphs. It can’t all be done in the same line, you have to specify specific functions each time which can be time-consuming and repetitive.

Default look is plain

The default look is very basic. If you want color and better backgrounds, you will have to specify it.

Great for fine-grained customization

You can change every little thing with the graph allowing you to get the exact graph you want.




Seaborn

High-level interface built on Matplotlib

Seaborn is built on top of Matplotlib, so it can use Matplotlib functions when needed, but it automates many common tasks like styling, grouping, and legends.

Polished style defaults

Unlike Matplotlib’s plain default look, Seaborn comes with clean, attractive themes (e.g., darkgrid, whitegrid, ticks using the set_style function) that make plots visually appealing with minimal code.

Statistical plotting built-in

Seaborn understands DataFrames and categorical variables. Functions like lineplot, barplot, and boxplot automatically handle grouping (hue, col, row) and aggregation (mean, confidence intervals), which saves a lot of manual coding.

Great for quick exploratory plots

With just one line of code, you can generate complex plots that summarize trends, distributions, or relationships. Perfect for exploratory data analysis (EDA) and quick insights.

title: Matplotlib vs. Seaborn: Same Plot, Different Styles
text:
Graphs

Matplotlib graph with minimum code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Load dataset from seaborn
tips = sns.load_dataset("tips")
plt.plot(tips["total_bill"], tips["tip"], "o") #"o" is making each datapoint a dot
plt.show()



Basic matplotlib graph




Seaborn graph with minimum code
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

tips = sns.load_dataset("tips")
sns.lineplot(x="total_bill", y="tip", data=tips, marker="o")
plt.show()



Basic seaborn graph



Basic Graph Comparison
As you can see, the code to implement the basic plots for both libraries is about the same. The only difference is that the matplotlib library sets the plot using plt.plot, while the seaborn library uses sns.lineplot. Seaborn also requires a x= and y= phrase in sns.lineplot while plt.plot can just have the data in order of x then y. I did add the marker=“o” for both libraries to make the data more visually appealing, but it is not required in the default graph. One things that is different is that the seaborn plot automatically adds lines between the different points while you would have to specifiy that with the matplotlib library.

title: Matplotlib vs. Seaborn: Same Plot, Different Styles
text:
Detailed Graphs

Detailed Matplotlib Graph
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

tips = sns.load_dataset("tips")

# Increase figure size
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 7))

# Get unique days for grouping
days = tips["day"].unique()
colors = plt.get_cmap("tab10").colors  # Color palette similar to Seaborn

# Plot each day separately
for i, day in enumerate(days):
    day_data = tips[tips["day"] == day]
    plt.plot(
        day_data["total_bill"], 
        day_data["tip"], 
        linestyle="--",     # Dashed line
        marker="o",         # Marker for each point
        color=colors[i % len(colors)], #assigns colors to the data
        label=day
    )

# Add title and labels
plt.title("Tips by Total Bill (Grouped by Day)", fontsize=16)
plt.xlabel("Total Bill ($)", fontsize=14)
plt.ylabel("Tip ($)", fontsize=14)

# Add grid
plt.grid(True, linestyle="--", linewidth=0.8)

# Customize legend
plt.legend(title="Day of Week", fontsize=12, title_fontsize=13)
plt.show()



Detailed matplotlib graph




Detailed Seaborn graph
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load seaborn's built-in dataset
tips = sns.load_dataset("tips")

# Set Seaborn style and context
sns.set_style("darkgrid")       # Dark grid background
sns.set_context("talk")         # Slightly larger labels for presentation

# Increase figure size
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 7))

sns.lineplot(
    data=tips,
    x="total_bill",
    y="tip",
    hue="day",            # Separate lines by day of week
    style="day",          # Different marker for each day
    markers=True,         # Show marker for each point
    linestyle="--",       # Dashed lines
    palette="tab10",      # Custom color palette
    ci=95                 # 95% confidence interval shading
)
plt.title("Tips by Total Bill (Grouped by Day)", fontsize=16)
plt.xlabel("Total Bill ($)", fontsize=14)
plt.ylabel("Tip ($)", fontsize=14)
plt.legend(title="Day of Week", fontsize=12, title_fontsize=13)
plt.show()



Detailed seaborn graph



Detailed Graph Comparison
These graphs may not be pretty, but they were made to show the main differences between the matplotlib and the seaborn libraries. The tips dataset is a dataset built into the seaborn library so we will use it for both graphs, but for the matplotlib graph, we will still only use functions from the matplotlib library. The main bits of code that the matplotlib library implemented to have the same graph as the seaborn library plot were the plt.get_camp(), and the for loop going through the different information. With this dataset, the matplotlib library needed the for loop seperate lines for each day of the week. The for loop splits the data by day, plots each subset with its own color, and manually adds a line. Seaborn is really covenient here because it does all this automatically with the hue function. Seaborn will also automatically choose styles based off of the hue function. We can specify the line type here to make it the same as the matplotlib plot, but without it, it would just choose one that it thinks looks the best. Seaborn also has the set_style() function that allows us to change the look of the entire plot. With darkgrid it gives you a dark background grid with white lines. Seaborn is built on matplotlib so it does still use the same method of assigning titles and axes as the matplotlib library.



Which One Is Better?
That really depends on what you want to do and the data you are graphing. If you want to customize every little thing in the graph, plotting functions such as cos or sin, or using very large datasets, matplotlib library is usually better. Seaborn is typically better if you just want a quick look at the data since it automatically adds colors and organizes the data on the graph in a neat way. It’s also more useful if you’re using a pandas dataframe and want statistical graphs that are beautiful. I invite you all to try out the matplotlib and seaborn library by asking AI for a dataset you can use to use the different features to see which one you prefer.

title: About Me
text:
Hi! My name is Ridge Atwood, and I am currently a junior at Brigham Young University majoring in Statistics with an emphasis in Data Science. I plan to enter the BYU Master’s Program in Data Science in Fall 2026.
My passion for data science comes from my love of problem solving, working with data to uncover insights, and an early interest in computer science. A mentor introduced me to data science as the perfect combination of both fields, and I’ve been excited about it ever since.
My career goal is to work in the financial industry, using data-driven decision making to improve financial strategies and outcomes.

title: Movie Rankings by Genre
text: Movies are a major part of popular culture, influencing trends, societal norms, and entertainment preferences. Understanding how different genres perform in terms of ratings and popularity over time can provide insights into audience preferences and the evolution of film trends. This project explores genre trends in movies released from 2016 to 2025, highlighting which genres are most common, highest rated by movie critics, and most popular by the public. It’s intereting to see if genres that were popular 10 years ago are still popular now. It’s also interesting to see which genres have prevailed for the last 10 years and see what that reflects about our society’s values, interests, and cultures. This data is most applicable to help filmmakers, analytics, or movie enthusiasts to understand audience interests that may impact the genres movies will have in the future.

title: Movie Rankings by Genre
text: Movies are a major part of popular culture, influencing trends, societal norms, and entertainment preferences. Understanding how different genres perform in terms of ratings and popularity over time can provide insights into audience preferences and the evolution of film trends. This project explores genre trends in movies released from 2016 to 2025, highlighting which genres are most common, highest rated by movie critics, and most popular by the public. It’s intereting to see if genres that were popular 10 years ago are still popular now. It’s also interesting to see which genres have prevailed for the last 10 years and see what that reflects about our society’s values, interests, and cultures. This data is most applicable to help filmmakers, analytics, or movie enthusiasts to understand audience interests that may impact the genres movies will have in the future.

title: Movie Rankings by Genre
text:
Motivating Question
The main questions this project addresses are:

How has genre popularity changed over the last 10+ years?
Which genres tend to receive the highest average ratings or highest popularity each year?

title: Movie Rankings by Genre
text:
Ethical Considerations / Data Gathering
The data was sourced from TMDb (The Movie Database) API, which allows me to publicly access movie metadata such as rating, genre, year released, popularity, and more. With TMDb, you’re allowed to use the API to access their data and use it as long as you gi ve them credit by putting their logo on your website or page if post information you got from their data. You are also not allowed to use their public API for commercial use. Using the API, there was no need to scrape data from their website, which would’ve been against their terms of use anyways. If you’re gathering a large amount of data, API requests should have a time.sleep(num) to respect TMDb rate limits to avoid server overload. Becuase all the data collected is aggregate metadata, there is no personal or sensitive information used. All these terms and policies regarding the use of TMDb’s API and data can be found at TMDb API.

title: Movie Rankings by Genre
text:
Steps to Get the Data

Sign up for a free TMDb account
Request an API key
Use Python with the requests library to query the API.
Collect relevant movie fields including:

Title
Release date
Vote average (rating)
Vote count
Popularity
Movie ID

To get genres of the movies:

Use genre API to get the different genres and IDs for movies
Map the genre to the movie ID

Loop through multiple pages of results to gather sufficient observations
Filter movies to include only those with at least 50 votes to focus on more reliable data.
Most movies have multiple genres so make each genre its own variable and set as True or False
Convert release dates to datetime and extract the year for analysis.
Aggregate genres using one-hot columns for counting and calculating average ratings or popularity.

title: Movie Rankings by Genre
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) Highlights
I was most interested in the genres that had the highest average ranking, but I wanted to first see the genres that were produced the most.
Below is a proportion table that shows the top 5 most common genres for both 2025 and from all our data and the percentage of movies that had these genres. You might be confused that the percentages don’t add up to 100%, but remember that each movie has multiple genres, so the percentages are only out of the total, not discounting other genres. There is overlap with the different genres and movies counted in each one. There are a total of 10,000 movies in the sample.



Genre
2025 Movies
Movies since 2016




Thriller
37%
24%


Drama
34%
42%


Comedy
33%
33%


Action
30%
19%


Horror
18%
16%



For 2025, the thriller genre has been the most common genre, with 37% of movies (totaling 139 movies) having this genre. Drama follows up behind it with 34% (totaling 125 movies). Both of these genres are often accompanies with each other and other genres. For example, most romance movies also have drama. Action and horror movies will often include thriller as well, and those genres are also in the top 5.
Looking at all the movies in the last 10 years, it seems that drama was also a very popular genre, being at 42% (totaling 4202 movies), while action and thrillers weren’t as popular. This gives us some insights as to today’s culture where people have lower attention spans which may be a leading cause to action and thriller movies being more popular.

Genres by Ranking
Because there were so many thriller and drama movies, I expected those genres to be the highest ranking movies. However, genres that weren’t even on the top 5 for amount of movies produced with that genre were ranked the highest. For 2025, the animation genre had the highest average ratings (7.28 avg rating). Since 2016, documentaries had the highest average rating (7.11 avg rating). The documentary rating really surprised me because in my personal life I’ve rarely watched documentaries and don’t know many people who enjoy watching documentaries. The ratings are a weighted average of votes on the movie, so it may be that only people who are interested in documentaries are voting on them, inflating that score.


Time Series Plot
In order to look at how the highest rated genre at changed over time, I made a time series plot showing this. 


Genres by Popularity
In order to see if the ratings were inflated, I also looked at the popularity of different genres. Popularity is determined by the total number of page views on the site for each movie so it may not completely represent if people are enjoying the movie, but that many people are watching the movie. Popularity is usually skewed towards newer movies since most people only visit IMDb to read summaries, reviews, and post reviews for new movies. Because of this, I will only look at genre popularity for movies released in 2025. Looking at popularity, I got different results from what rankings show. The fantasy genre is the most popular (54.7 avg) while the documentary genre is the least popular (2.3). This reinforces my belief that the documentary genre most likely has the highest average rating because the majority of people who are voting for the ranking of documentaries enjoy watching them.

title: Movie Rankings by Genre
text:
Summary
From the analysis that I was able to do, I was able to find that the current most popular genres are most likely fantasy and animation. These genres have been producing high rated movies is the last couple of years. This can be due to the continual rise in digital imaging, allowing for better animation. This makes the movies easier to create and better to watch as well. Fantasy has been a popular genre, which is unsuprising considering the widespread popular movies since 2016 such as the Avengers movies. Just looking at highest rated movies on average wasn’t very helpful as it could be extremely skewed with low view counts but high ratings. The most useful was to compare ratings and popularity to see what genres the fans were enjoying. These were fantasy and animation. Looking at the proportion table and count of movies was useful to see what genres Hollywood wanted to focus on and wanted to produce. We saw that within the last 10 years, there has been an increase in the percentage of movies that are considered action and thrillers, showcasing today’s culture and interest in fast-paced movies.

title: Movie Rankings by Genre
text:
Additional Information

TMDb (The Movie Database) API Documentation – Learn how to access and use TMDb’s public movie data.

TMDb Terms of Use – Review TMDb’s data usage policy and attribution requirements.

Pandas Documentation – For data cleaning, transformation, and aggregation in Python.

Matplotlib Documentation – For creating and saving data visualizations.

Kaggle Movie Datasets – You can look here for datasets similar to this.
